creator: thomas.liebscher@intercomponentware.com
text:
The situation is similar to the one described in bug# 9657.

I'm running apache 2.0.52 with OpenSSL 0.9.7e on Linux (SUSE SLES8).
The log file shows entries like:
...
[Sun Jan 02 19:59:15 2005] [debug] ssl_engine_io.c(1517): OpenSSL: I/O error, 5 
bytes expected to read on BIO#8487188 [mem: 848e808]
[Sun Jan 02 19:59:15 2005] [info] (70007)The timeout specified has expired: SSL 
input filter read failed.
[Sun Jan 02 19:59:15 2005] [debug] ssl_engine_kernel.c(1774): OpenSSL: Write: 
SSL negotiation finished successfully
[Sun Jan 02 19:59:15 2005] [info] Connection to child 0 closed with standard 
shutdown(server record.de.lifesensor.com:443, client 172.31.10.169)
...

The error is sporadically, the pages work most of the time.

Do you have "KeepAlive On" and is the standard disable-keepalive-for-MSIE
SetEnvIf configured as per the default config?

The "read timed out" message *followed* by "negotiation finished successfully"
does seem contradictory.  Is the MSIE error returned immediately, or after a delay?
creator: jorton@redhat.com

text:
KeepAlive is on and the following standard section is included (what you 
probably meant by "standard disable-keepalive-for-MSIE").
...
BrowserMatch "Mozilla/2" nokeepalive
BrowserMatch "MSIE 4\.0b2;" nokeepalive downgrade-1.0 force-response-1.0
BrowserMatch "RealPlayer 4\.0" force-response-1.0
BrowserMatch "Java/1\.0" force-response-1.0
BrowserMatch "JDK/1\.0" force-response-1.0
...
The MSIE error (page not found) is returned after a delay of about 3-5sec, but 
is not long enough to get into the range of the Timeout setting (Timeout 30).
creator: thomas.liebscher@intercomponentware.com
jorton@redhat.com
text:
I meant this SetEnvIf in ssl.conf:

SetEnvIf User-Agent ".*MSIE.*" \
         nokeepalive ssl-unclean-shutdown \
         downgrade-1.0 force-response-1.0

Marking closed: this is an expected failure from not using the SetEnvIf
statement in the default config to enable unclean shutdown for MSIE.  Though see
bug 34452 if you're using a reverse-proxy.
creator: jorton@redhat.com
